com.mobilerq.android.sdk

Class MrqSdk

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.mobilerq.android.sdk.MrqSdk

  • public class MrqSdk
extends Object
    Android client for MobileRQ. Typically one instance of MrqSdk would be initialized by calling init from an Android application's Application class. The application's Activity classes can get a reference to the MrqSdk instance by implementing MrqSdkListener. Share app user context by setting setDataProvider(MrqDataProvider). When MrqUserContext has changed, call refresh() to get new matching content.
    See Also:
    MrqDataProvider, MrqSdkListener, MobileRQ Documentation

      • pushMessageRecognized

        public static boolean pushMessageRecognized(android.os.Bundle data)
        Determine if a push message was sent by MobileRQ. If your application is already handling push messages, this method can be used to determine if a push message was sent by MobileRQ.
        Parameters:
        data - the Bundle data from a com.google.android.gms.gcm.GcmListenerService#onMessageReceived(String, Bundle) implementation
        Returns:
        boolean indicating whether or not the push message was sent by MobileRQ

      • forceContentUpdate

        public static void forceContentUpdate(android.content.Context context)
        Send content to all registered update listeners. The content will be getMatchingContent(). When there is no matching content, refresh() will be called.
        Parameters:
        context - The app context

      • onGcmMessageReceived

        public static void onGcmMessageReceived(android.content.Context context,
                        android.os.Bundle data)
        Inspects the data Bundle from a com.google.android.gms.gcm.GcmListenerService#onMessageReceived(String, Bundle) implementation, and updates all the content views if the Bundle came from a MobileRQ push message.
        Parameters:
        context - The app context
        data - the Bundle data from a com.google.android.gms.gcm.GcmListenerService#onMessageReceived(String, Bundle) implementation

      • openContent

        public static void openContent(android.content.Context context,
               MrqContent content)
        Open MrqContent.getUrl() in the browser if it's not null. This tracks a click.
        Parameters:
        context - The context
        content - The content. Null content is ignored.

        Parameters:

      • setGcmRegistrationId

        public void setGcmRegistrationId(String gcmRegistrationId)
        Set the Google Cloud Messaging Registration ID. You must register a project with GCM to get a registration ID. A registration ID is required before MobileRQ can send messages to the app via Google Cloud Messaging.
        Parameters:
        gcmRegistrationId - The Google Cloud Message Registration ID.
        See Also:
        Google Cloud Messaging Getting Started

      • startMonitoringLocation

        public void startMonitoringLocation()
        Start monitoring the location of the device. This will create a new service called MrqLocationService which handles any location updates from the device. The service will continue running until stopMonitoringLocation() is called (it will continue running even when the application is closed).

        The MrqLocationService uses a LocationListener to monitor location changes. It will use a default LocationRequest with a 5 minute interval, a 1 minute fastestInterval, a 45 meter smallestDisplacement, and PRIORITY_BALANCED_POWER_ACCURACY priority. To use a custom LocationRequest, use startMonitoringLocation(LocationRequest locationRequest).

        MobileRQ will use this information to send push messages to devices if you have location triggered push messages configured.

        Throws:
        NullPointerException - when locationRequest is null

      • startMonitoringLocation

        public void startMonitoringLocation(LocationRequest locationRequest)
        Start monitoring the location of the device. This will create a new service called MrqLocationService which handles any location updates from the device. The service will continue running until stopMonitoringLocation() is called (it will continue running even when the application is closed).

        The MrqLocationService uses a LocationListener to monitor location changes, and will use the provided LocationRequest.

        MobileRQ will use this information to send push messages to devices if you have location triggered push messages configured.

        Parameters:
        locationRequest - The LocationRequest the MrqLocationService will use
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - when locationRequest is null

      • stopMonitoringLocation

        public void stopMonitoringLocation()
        Stop monitoring the location of this device. This method will end the MrqLocationService.

      • refresh

        public void refresh()
        Refresh content. Call this when MrqUserContext has changed.

      • refreshOffers

        @Deprecated
public void refreshOffers()
        Deprecated. Use refresh()
        Refresh content. This is the same as refresh().

      • setDataProvider

        public void setDataProvider(MrqDataProvider dataProvider)
        Set the MrqDataProvider to be used to determine the user's context.

        NOTE: this can be your main Activity, if it implements MrqDataProvider

        Parameters:
        dataProvider - - a object that implements MrqDataProvider. Its currentUserContext() method will be called as needed by MrqSdk.
        See Also:
        MrqDataProvider

      • setApid

        public void setApid(String apid)
        Set the Urban Airship APID associated with the device. This is optional, but it is necessary in order for push messaging using Urban Airship.
        Parameters:
        apid - - the APID to be used for push messaging.

        Parameters:

      • getCustomerId

        public String getCustomerId()
        Get the customer ID
        Returns:
        The customer ID or null if not set

      • setCustomerId

        public void setCustomerId(String customerId)
        Set the customer ID that uniquely identifies this app user.

        You may use any value for customer ID, but choosing the correct customer ID is critical to making MobileRQ easy to use. Your customer ID must have the following properties:

        • Uniquely identify the customer - First and last name is not a good customer ID because many customers share names.
        • It must be stable (rarely change) - Home or work street address is not a good ID because it changes each time your customer moves.
        • Available in your mobile app and backend systems - Both your app and backend databases must agree on the customer ID so you can send updates to the MobileRQ Customer API.

        The Customer ID can be based on PII, but it’s your responsibility to securely share this with MobileRQ. Consider using bcrypt to create a hash of the PII. IDs you could hash and send to MobileRQ as the customer ID are:

        • Email address
        • Social login ID
        • Government ID
        Parameters:
        customerId - The customer ID

      • updateLocation

        public void updateLocation(android.location.Location location)
        Set the location and refresh it with MobileRQ. Use this method if your application is already location aware. This method should not be used if you are allowing MrqSdk to monitor location automatically using startMonitoringLocation / stopMonitoringLocation.
        Parameters:
        location - the last known Location of the device

      • getLastLocation

        public android.location.Location getLastLocation()
        Get the last location passed to updateLocation or collected by the monitor started by startMonitoringLocation.
        Returns:
        The last known location or null if no location has been set.

      • getMatchingContent

        public List<MrqContent> getMatchingContent()
        Get a copy of matching content, sorted by the MobileRQ service.
        Returns:
        matching content list, or empty list of no content matches.
